publisher.value: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN)

name.value: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN)

description.value:
A fragment of the set of healthcare surveillance vocabulary concepts and associated identifiers intended solely for data submissions to the National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN). Other uses are not recommended.
The CDCNHSN code system is highly specialized to meet the needs of NHSN surveillance reporting, is undergoing changes, and is not recommended for creating value sets to be used outside of NHSN.

display.value: Breast abscess or mastitis
Myocarditis or pericarditis
Clinical sepsis
Deep incisional primary surgical site infection (SSI)

Eye infection, other than conjunctivitis
Gastrointestinal tract infection (esophagus, stomach, small and large bowel, and rectum) excluding gastroenteritis and appendicitis

Intraabdominal infection, not specified elsewhere including gallbladder, bile ducts, liver (excluding viral hepatitis), spleen, pancreas, peritoneum, subphrenic or subdiaphragmatic space, or other intraabdominal tissue or area not specified elsewhere
Intracranial infection (brain abscess, subdural or epidural infection, encephalitis)
Joint or bursa infection

Oral cavity infection (mouth, tongue, or gums)
Other infections of the male or female reproductive tract (epididymis, testes, prostate, vagina, ovaries, uterus, or other deep pelvic tissues, excluding endometritis or vaginal cuff infections)
Other infections of the urinary tract (kidney, ureter, bladder, urethra, or tissue surrounding the retroperitoneal or perinephric space)

Not cultured
Blood culture not done or no organisms detected in blood
New onset/change in sputum
New onset/worsening cough, dyspnea, tachypnea
Other evidence of infection found

New onset or change in sputum, increased secretions or increased suctioning

Wheezing, rales or rhonchi

New or progressive and persistent infiltrate

One positive culture with >=100,000 cfu/ml with no more than 2 species of microorganisms
Positive dipstick for leukocyte esterase or nitrate
Greater than or equal to 2 positive urine cultures with >=100 cfu/ml of same uropathogen from non-voided specimen
One positive culture with <=100,000 cfu/ml of a single uropathogen in patient being treated with an effective antimicrobial agent for UTI
Greater than or equal to 2 positive urine cultures with >=100,000 cfu/ml with no more than 2 organisms
Positive detection of viral antigen or antibody
Fourfold rise in paired sera for pathogen
Positive culture or microimmunofluorescence of Legionella species
Legionella pneumophila serogroup 1 antigens in urine
Fourfold rise in Legionella pneumophila antibody titer
Matching positive blood and sputum cultures with Candida species
Fungi or Pneumocystis carinii from lower respiratory tract specimen
Other positive laboratory tests
More than 15 colonies cultured from intravascular cannula tip using semi-quantitative culture method
Positive Gram stain when culture is negative or not done
Common commensal from >=2 blood cultures

Positive quantitative culture from lower respiratory tract (LRT) specimen

Positive culture of skin contaminant
Positive blood culture
Histopathologic exam with abscess formation or lung parenchyma invasion by fungal hyphae
Acute onset of diarrhea (liquid stools for >12 hours)
Worsening gas exchange
Apnea, tachypnea, nasal flaring with retraction of chest wall or grunting

A new antimicrobial agent(s) is started, and is continued for >=4 days
